text: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis to step down.

@realmoney At 515 S&P futures are trading about 45 handles above the day's lows. In my view we are headed to a year end rally. Many investors are justifiably fearful but I expect (and am hopeful) that when we look back a month from now many may rue that they didnt take advantage

of buying at today's levels. Several commentators mentioned the likelihood of a large allocation program - something I referenced earlier in the day. (Late in the day Wells Fargo talked about a $64 billion pension buy by month's end) I now take the contrarian position to the

crowd, again! The time to have sold was September when the S&P was 450 handles higher, not now. At least that is my view - given that S&P for first time in 2 years has reached fair market value. But make your own decision. @realmoney
relatively meaningless imho

"Opportunities come infrequently. When it rains gold, put out the bucket, not the thimble." - Warren Buffett It's not exactly raining gold now and it might not be time to take out the bucket but it may be raining silver and it is time for me to take out the cup. @jimcramer

Tears on the Market's Pillow Provides An Opportunity * Emotion is taking over piped.video/watch?v=UBgAj4cN…

Though I still remain materially underinvested, I am employing this strategy of buying the dip on a scale because Mr. Market, based on my calculus, has finally met (and arguably penetrated the higher end of my projected "fair market value") that I have had for about two years.

Meanwhile and importantly, my worst case, discussed in 15 Surprise for 2019 of 2200 S&P Index (considered outrageous by many when I wrote the List with the S&P at 2750) is only about 9-10% below current levels). The recent market swoon has perhaps created the most favorable

upside reward v. downside risk - for the near term (next 1-2 months) - in almost two years. A number of individual stocks now have an even better reward/risk ratio than the S&P Index. "Opportunities come infrequently. When it rains gold, put out the bucket, not the thimble.”

- Warren Buffett Being greedy when others are fearful (h/t The Oracle of Omaha) is easy to say but more difficult to execute when stock prices are falling so swiftly. It's not exactly raining gold now (see quote above) and it might not be time to take out the bucket but it may

be raining silver and it is time for me to take out the cup. Short term and long term investors should be rejoicing and taking advantage of bargains - though the sledding in 2019 is bound to be difficult. Nevertheless, this approach has served me well over the years @jimcrameri
Bingo! With S&P cash now at 2450 - for the first time that I can remember - we are exactly at my long held "fair market value" of the S&P Index (of between 2400-2500). $SPY @realmoney @jimcramer
$BAC $WFC $JPM green. @realmoney @jimcramer

The Bull Market in Complacency - that existed for two years - has morphed into a market of increased fear and much more investor pessimism. Stated simply, upside reward v. downside risk has changed materially from the levels of only two months ago.
I am a buyer today on this weakness - as I continue to trade unemotionally and opportunistically.

@realmoney S&P cash is now at 2472 - almost in the middle of my "fair market valuation" of 2400-2500 (discussed in this morning's opener) That compares to the September, 2018 peak of approximately 2920 (450 S&P handles higher).

On @realmoney Say No To Idiots. I Am! * I am tuning out to portions of the media now - as they have become merchants of attention with little value added content * And will spend more time on research is a more demanding market setting. I made the following tweet this morning:

The same (self confident) bad actors who were long in 2007-08 and lost a large portion of capital have reappeared in the media (especially on CNBC) over the last few years. They are generally not transparent and unaccountable - as they attempt to sell a service or strive to

expand viewership. It is rare that any admit making a mistake and they rarely say "I don't know." Few have learned from history and most are destined to repeat those past mistakes. Dont be that sucker and dont be poisoned by their pablum . Read... Who Is Swimming Naked?

realinvestmentadvice.com/kas… … Going forward I will no longer be critical on Twitter or in my Diary of these bad actors because my dial has been turned off as of today. It's gotten too easy to point out their continued failures and lack of admission of mistakes.
I have determined - in their search for attention, viewers and subscribers to services - that they will never be accountable. Fool me once shame on you. Fool me twice shame on me. Over and out.

@realmoney From this morning $MU Provides More Lessons We should once again learn from the dramatic drop in share prices of former market darlings (e.g. ($AAPL) , ($FB) , ($NVDA) and ($MU) )

Resist the temptation of the consensus and "Group Stink" and recognize the value of being a contrarian: * Remain skeptical to the core - especially of the "shiny investment objects" and asset classes (e.g. Crypt0) du jour

* Do your own homework - turn off the television and look down at the balance sheet and income statements * Always calculate upside reward v. downside risk (buy value, sell hype) * Recognize that the investment mosaic is complicated

* Avoid single variable stock selection strategies that appear to make the trading/investment game easy (flow, "unusual options activity," a stock price chart, etc.) * Respect your hard earned capital - few others (that you might be paying attention to) will
* Develop a sense of history
